webTitle: Bank of England: no interest rate rises till unemployment drops to 7% -as it happened

fields.standfirst:
Governor Mark Carney says no rate rises until jobless rate falls to 7%.
• Q&A from 10.45pm
• News story online here
• Reaction from noon
• Poll: Is Carney doing a good job?
• See the reports yourself
fields.body:
5.08pm BST

Closing summary

In the end it was Mark Carney's day. The new governor of the Bank of England announced that interest rates will stay at record lows until unemployment falls to 7% - an unprecedented bit of forward planning that divided economists.

The TUC said the new governor's outlook was "a much needed dose of realism after yesterday's 'Boom Britain' headlines" (12.32) but the free-market thinktank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, branded it "the most dangerous development in UK monetary policy since the late 1980s" (2.04)

The Guardian's economics correspondent Phillip Inman, sums up five things what we learned.

The biggest news from the Eurozone was a big acceleration in German factory output data, while Portugal's unemployment fell slightly.

So that is all for today. Thank you for following, for your comments, and have a good evening.

4.51pm BST

Spanish 'white elephant' airport up for sale

A little piece of Spain's property boom - the airport at Ciudad Real in La Mancha - is up for auction. The starting price is €100m (£86m), a steal, bearing in mind that it cost the Spanish taxpayer €1bn to build.

Stephen Burgen, reporting from Barcelona, writes that "the airport is one of the most egregious examples of the excesses of Spain's building boom".

The administrators of the airport say that its proponents "never carried out an investment analysis" nor did they produce a realistic business model and "produced a financial plan that was not based on any studies of the market or of demand that would justify the anticipated traffic." Ciudad Real has a population of just 75,000 and many Spaniards would have trouble finding it on a map.

Here is Stephen's article:

Yours for €100m: Spanish airport, mint condition, one careless owner

Updated at 4.52pm BST

4.38pm BST

Wall Street opens down

Stocks on Wall St opened lower for the third day in the row, as investors continue to fret about the US Federal Reserve winding down its stimulus programme.

The S+P fell 0.5% to 1,688 points, the Dow Jones was also down 0.5% to 15,438. The dollar fell against the pound, which was buoyed up by the promise of low interest rates.

This slip was little surprise to most investors, coming one day after a senior Fed official threw more cold water on the markets, when he said the Fed would scale back its massive bond-buying programme.

Charles Evans, president of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank, said:

We are quite likely to reduce the flow of purchases rate starting later this year - I couldn’t tell you exactly which month that will be - and it's likely to wind down over time in a couple or few stages.

The Fed holds its next policy meeting in mid September.

Updated at 4.40pm BST

4.21pm BST

New broom at India's central bank

 As it is central bank day, here is a look at the new boss of India's central bank, Raghuram Rajan, who takes over in September.

As the Guardian reported yesterday, Rajan will take over at the Reserve Bank of India amid fears that the much-debated phasing out of America's stimulus package will push up the value of the dollar and trigger a currency crisis in emerging markets. 

Andy Mukherjee at Reuters Breaking Views writes that Rajan must show he is as good at managing financial crises as he is at predicting them.

When he was chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, Rajan was a prescient critic of a finance-fuelled credit boom, warning of “hidden tail risks” as early as 2005. His first task as India’s new central bank governor will be to avert the country’s looming currency crisis.

The Indian rupee is in free fall. It touched a record low against the dollar on Aug. 6...So how will Rajan avert a disaster? His stance is pro-growth, says a person who attended a meeting between him and private-sector economists four days before the RBI launched its growth-busting emergency measures. But in order to lower domestic interest rates at a time when US real rates are rising, Rajan will either need to introduce capital controls – as Malaysia did in 1998 – or win the confidence of global investors in India’s growth revival plan. Rajan has strong credentials, and a winsome personality. What he doesn’t have is time.

Perhaps Mark Carney's task at the Bank of England is not so complicated after all...

3.42pm BST

Mr Samaras goes to Washington

The Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras has begun a much-anticipated visit to the United States, where he is meeting leading businessmen in the hope of luring investment today and holds crucial talks with US president Barack Obama tomorrow.

Helena Smith, the Guardian's Athens correspondent, explains why the trip is so important:

It’s been nigh on nine years since a Greek prime minister held official talks with a US president in Washington. If timing is everything in politics, then the timing of Antonis Samaras’ White House sit-down with president Barack Obama on Thursday could not be more prescient.

Four years into Europe’s worst economic crisis since the second world war, Greece, the nation where it all began, remains the front line state: the one EU member where it could all get better or all get worse. The US administration is not unsympathetic. From the outset, leading democrats have opposed the politics of austerity, with Obama at times almost pleading with Berlin to abandon its harsh fiscal policies in favour of development and growth. Obama, who has also defended the New Deal social welfare policies of the 1930s, is the only leader Samaras has not yet met in private. 

With the economy expected to be the focus of tomorrow’s talks, the Greek prime minister who like the US president also attended Harvard, will almost certainly play on those sentiments.

Now that Athens has succeeded in securing its place in the Eurozone - a place that was far from secure when the newly-installed leader met Angela Merkel for the first time this time last year - the Greek government, more than ever, is in need of allies to promote the one remedy that will get the debt-crippled country out of its austerity-induced economic death spiral – growth. That more than anything will mean persuading Berlin, the provider of most of the rescue funds Greece has received to date, to change tack.

Samaras’ aides are hoping that after Germany’s September elections the EU powerhouse will soften its stance not least on the potentially explosive issue of an official sector debt restructuring – now seen, even by the IMF, as the only way of making Athens’ monumental debt load sustainable. But the Greek government also knows it is in no position to raise the issue itself – a haircut, after all, would cost German tax payers in excess of €30 bn. Instead, much depends internationally on acknowledgement of the giant steps Greece has made in fiscal consolidation and this is where Washington comes in. Forward Guidance day at the Bank of England - at 10.30am

Good morning.

Mark Carney has made a pretty sure-footed start since replacing Sir Mervyn King as Bank of England governor five weeks ago. Today, the central banker from Canada faces his first big test – ushering Britain into a new world of Forward Guidance.

For the first time in its history, the Bank will lay out how long it will leave UK interest rates at their current record low levels.

Economists believe the BoE could pledge not to touch borrowing costs until unemployment had fallen to a certain level, or until the UK has racked up more growth. Or perhaps for a fixed period of time.

The move gives Carney and crew an extra weapon in their monetary policy armory – and with rates down at 0.5% and £375bn of quantitative easing already deployed (to buy UK government debt), they could use it.

As Vicky Redwood of Capital Economics explains:

Guidance could play an important role in the coming months if it keeps rate expectations anchored as the recovery picks up pace.

The details will come at Carney's first press conference, for the Bank's Quarterly Inflation Report, in which UK growth forecasts are likely to be raised...

...And that makes today's task rather trickier that it appeared back in March when chancellor George Osborne invited the BoE to consider forward guidance. Then, Britain feared a triple-dip recession. Now, it knows that the double-dip never happened.

The economy is still smaller than in 2008, but we've seen plenty of encouraging private sector data in recent days – including the best month for service sector activity since 2006, and a jump in industrial output.

With some newspapers (not this one) even claiming that Britain is "booming", should the Bank really be promising to keep the party going?

However, with real wages falling and living standards squeezed, Carney can certainly argue that the UK economy needs all the help it can get.

The quarterly inflation report is released at 10.30am BST, immediately followed by a press conference inside the Bank where a flock of Britain's economics journalists will quiz Carney about his plans.

I'll track all the action in the liveblog -- along with other events across the financial markets, the world economy, and the eurozone. It's an otherwise quiet day, though, so Carney gets the limelight.

fields.bodyText: In the end it was Mark Carney's day. The new governor of the Bank of England announced that interest rates will stay at record lows until unemployment falls to 7% - an unprecedented bit of forward planning that divided economists. The TUC said the new governor's outlook was "a much needed dose of realism after yesterday's 'Boom Britain' headlines" (12.32) but the free-market thinktank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, branded it "the most dangerous development in UK monetary policy since the late 1980s" (2.04) The Guardian's economics correspondent Phillip Inman, sums up five things what we learned. The biggest news from the Eurozone was a big acceleration in German factory output data, while Portugal's unemployment fell slightly. So that is all for today. Thank you for following, for your comments, and have a good evening. A little piece of Spain's property boom - the airport at Ciudad Real in La Mancha - is up for auction. The starting price is €100m (£86m), a steal, bearing in mind that it cost the Spanish taxpayer €1bn to build. Stephen Burgen, reporting from Barcelona, writes that "the airport is one of the most egregious examples of the excesses of Spain's building boom". The administrators of the airport say that its proponents "never carried out an investment analysis" nor did they produce a realistic business model and "produced a financial plan that was not based on any studies of the market or of demand that would justify the anticipated traffic." Ciudad Real has a population of just 75,000 and many Spaniards would have trouble finding it on a map. Here is Stephen's article: Yours for €100m: Spanish airport, mint condition, one careless owner Stocks on Wall St opened lower for the third day in the row, as investors continue to fret about the US Federal Reserve winding down its stimulus programme. The S+P fell 0.5% to 1,688 points, the Dow Jones was also down 0.5% to 15,438. The dollar fell against the pound, which was buoyed up by the promise of low interest rates. This slip was little surprise to most investors, coming one day after a senior Fed official threw more cold water on the markets, when he said the Fed would scale back its massive bond-buying programme. Charles Evans, president of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank, said: We are quite likely to reduce the flow of purchases rate starting later this year - I couldn’t tell you exactly which month that will be - and it's likely to wind down over time in a couple or few stages. The Fed holds its next policy meeting in mid September. As it is central bank day, here is a look at the new boss of India's central bank, Raghuram Rajan, who takes over in September. As the Guardian reported yesterday, Rajan will take over at the Reserve Bank of India amid fears that the much-debated phasing out of America's stimulus package will push up the value of the dollar and trigger a currency crisis in emerging markets. Andy Mukherjee at Reuters Breaking Views writes that Rajan must show he is as good at managing financial crises as he is at predicting them. When he was chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, Rajan was a prescient critic of a finance-fuelled credit boom, warning of “hidden tail risks” as early as 2005. His first task as India’s new central bank governor will be to avert the country’s looming currency crisis. The Indian rupee is in free fall. It touched a record low against the dollar on Aug. 6...So how will Rajan avert a disaster? His stance is pro-growth, says a person who attended a meeting between him and private-sector economists four days before the RBI launched its growth-busting emergency measures. But in order to lower domestic interest rates at a time when US real rates are rising, Rajan will either need to introduce capital controls – as Malaysia did in 1998 – or win the confidence of global investors in India’s growth revival plan. Rajan has strong credentials, and a winsome personality. What he doesn’t have is time. Perhaps Mark Carney's task at the Bank of England is not so complicated after all... The Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras has begun a much-anticipated visit to the United States, where he is meeting leading businessmen in the hope of luring investment today and holds crucial talks with US president Barack Obama tomorrow. Helena Smith, the Guardian's Athens correspondent, explains why the trip is so important: It’s been nigh on nine years since a Greek prime minister held official talks with a US president in Washington. If timing is everything in politics, then the timing of Antonis Samaras’ White House sit-down with president Barack Obama on Thursday could not be more prescient. Four years into Europe’s worst economic crisis since the second world war, Greece, the nation where it all began, remains the front line state: the one EU member where it could all get better or all get worse. The US administration is not unsympathetic. From the outset, leading democrats have opposed the politics of austerity, with Obama at times almost pleading with Berlin to abandon its harsh fiscal policies in favour of development and growth. Obama, who has also defended the New Deal social welfare policies of the 1930s, is the only leader Samaras has not yet met in private. With the economy expected to be the focus of tomorrow’s talks, the Greek prime minister who like the US president also attended Harvard, will almost certainly play on those sentiments. Now that Athens has succeeded in securing its place in the Eurozone - a place that was far from secure when the newly-installed leader met Angela Merkel for the first time this time last year - the Greek government, more than ever, is in need of allies to promote the one remedy that will get the debt-crippled country out of its austerity-induced economic death spiral – growth. That more than anything will mean persuading Berlin, the provider of most of the rescue funds Greece has received to date, to change tack. Samaras’ aides are hoping that after Germany’s September elections the EU powerhouse will soften its stance not least on the potentially explosive issue of an official sector debt restructuring – now seen, even by the IMF, as the only way of making Athens’ monumental debt load sustainable. But the Greek government also knows it is in no position to raise the issue itself – a haircut, after all, would cost German tax payers in excess of €30 bn. Instead, much depends internationally on acknowledgement of the giant steps Greece has made in fiscal consolidation and this is where Washington comes in. A kind word from Obama could help immensely, say aides, in not only raising the off-limits subject, but giving succor to the government in what will surely be a very difficult winter and fall. Much more than just a photo-opportunity, Samaras is hoping his talks with Obama will send a message of optimism as much to Greeks as to the international creditors keeping the country’s economy afloat. Forward guidance might be causing hearts to beat faster in London, but in Canada it is old news. The BBC has a helpful piece on Mark Carney’s record at the Bank of Canada, where he launched a policy of forward guidance - or “conditional commitment”. Back in 2009, with western economies pitifully weakened after the financial crisis, Carney made a “simple statement” to Canadians to keep interest rates at a record low of 0.25% until the second quarter of 2010. Economic growth duly picked up, but critics say the low rates stoked a mortgage boom. As David Madani of Capital Economics told the BBC Low interest rates in Canada have definitely prolonged the boom, but households have also been part of the problem because they have been prepared to throw money at housing over the past few years. I think when you look back at Mark Carney's record in 5 or 10 years' time, I think it will actually look quite ordinary. So what will be the judgement on Mr Carney at the end of his term in 2018? We are not waiting 5 years to come to rough conclusions and you can vote in the Guardian's poll - has Mark Carney lived up to expectations? And now the bookies' verdict on the Bank of England's forward guidance policy. Ladbrokes reckons Mark Carney is odds on to break his shiny new policy before he finishes his term in 2018. Alex Donohue of Ladbrokes says: The forward guidance policy looks odds-on to be broken at some point in Carney's tenure. We're not sure about offering huge odds about it never happening either. And anyone who fancies George Osborne as the next governor of the Bank of England can get odds 66/1. Good news for Angela Merkel ahead of September's elections. German industrial output has risen at its fastest pace for two years. Industrial orders rebounded up 2.4% in June, following a dip in May, comfortably beating economists' expectations. The Ministry of Economics said some of the rebound was down to technical reasons - those pesky bank holidays that disrupt economic data. But economists sound pretty pleased. ING analyst Carsten Brzeski: "It looks as if the German economy is again walking on two feet: solid private consumption and strengthening industrial activity." Hot off the wires: Portugal's new treasury secretary Joaquim Pais Jorge has resigned after just a few weeks in the job over a controversy linked to his previous job at Citgroup I took this difficult decision because I would never allow controversies surrounding my professional life, which I have never hidden, to be used as a political weapon against the government. Via Reuters This comes after news that Portugal's unemployment rate has dropped to 16.4% between April to June, down from a record 17.7% at the start of the year. So just a bit less terrible. Unemployment is now at its lowest point in two years. But it looks like some of the new jobs are seasonal, with the biggest fall in unemployment recorded in the Algarve. The Institute of Directors are also not in the Carney fan club. Here is Graeme Leach, the IOD's chief economist. Forward guidance doesn't really take us forward, and we are very concerned at the use of monetary policy to chase unemployment. We're still looking at an economy which will struggle to reach trend growth, let alone exceed it. Strong words from the Institute of Economic Affairs, the free-market think tank, which has described forward guidance as "the most dangerous development in UK monetary policy since the late 1980s". Here is the IEA's Philip Booth: Monetary policy should be designed to ensure that we have stable prices. The level of unemployment is mainly determined by a range of factors such a labour market regulation, the benefits system, tax rates and so on. To try to use monetary policy to reduce unemployment when inflation is already above target is playing with fire and could lead us down the road that we followed in the 1970s. This move also calls into question the independence of the Monetary Policy Committee and the Bank of England's ability to fulfil its statutory duties A quick riposte from former MPC member Danny Blanchflower. If the IEA think it's a bad idea, then it must be good. Hi, Jennifer Rankin taking over from Graeme Wearden, who is starting his well-deserved holiday. This morning's decision by the Bank of England to tie interest rates to unemployment was a momentous one. Here is the verdict from the Guardian's economics editor Larry Elliott. The Bank of England has never had interest rates this low in its 319-year history and is on course to keep them pegged at 0.5% for longer than it look the Allies to win the Second World War, longer than the French Revolution between the storming of the Bastille and the topping of Robespierre and longer than it took the Beatles to record everything from Love Me Do to Abbey Road. Quite a period, in other words, and evidence of just how fragile Threadneedle Street thinks the economy remains following the deepest recession and the slowest recovery in recorded history. Britain’s predilection for booms and busts in the past 40 years means that a good old-fashioned housing bubble, with its attendant balance of payments deficits, cannot be ruled out. The Bank, though, considers this to be a risk worth running. It has plenty of experience of recessions caused by over-heating and knows how to deal with them. But the slump of 2007-09 was different. None of the normal policy tools were effective with a downturn caused by global financial systems failure. That’s why exceptional measures were deemed necessary. And are still deemed necessary, whatever the side effects may prove to be. Shadow chancellor Ed Balls has thrown his support behind Mark Carney, welcoming the 'leadership' shown by the new governor today. Balls also used the new unemployment target as a stick to poke chancellor George Osborne: Balls said: By recognising the importance of policy action to support jobs and growth, at last we are seeing the Governor show the leadership we have failed to see over the last three years and are still not seeing from the Chancellor. Mark Carney is right to warn that the recovery is weak. It is the slowest on record and families are facing a growing cost of living crisis. But the new Governor is not a miracle worker and monetary policy cannot do the job alone. As we and the IMF have consistently said George Osborne must finally act to support the economy and also help families feeling the squeeze. Balls also warned cautioned that the Bank will have to show "careful vigilance" to avoid inflation now taking off. And on that note, I'm handing over the live blog to my colleague Jennifer Rankin. My personal forward guidance is that the ferry from Portsmouth to Caen leaves tonight, and I'd better be on it..... Cheers all. GW Shares have fallen in London since the Bank of England announced its new forward guidance, with the FTSE 100 down 52 points, or 0.8%, at 6,551. Traders say that Mark Carney's gloomy comments about the state of the economy are to blame. The governor warned that Britain is not yet at escape velocity, and pointedly said this was the weakest recovery in over a hundred years. As Logic Investments director Khilan Shah put it: The forward guidance is not great. Sky's Ed Conway tweets two other important sections from today's report: Today's forward guidance policy from the Bank of England (online here) includes this chart showing how it expects the unemployment rate to fall in the coming years (assuming rates remain at 0 .5%): As a fan chart, it shows the likely path of joblessness -- the darker the colour, the higher the chances of the forecast being right. Mortgage brokers are already predicting that interest rates on five year fixed rate loans will now start heading down, our Money editor Patrick Collinson flags up. He explains: Jonathan Harris of mortgage broker Anderson Harris said: “We expect fixed-rate mortgages to fall even further on the back of this announcement. They may already be at historic lows but if lenders are to convince borrowers to opt for a fix when interest rates are highly unlikely to rise, then pricing needs to be attractive.” As financial journalist James Andrews tweeted, two year fixed rates now look “pointless” as they are usually priced above ‘tracker’ rates that follow the Bank of England base rate: Patrick adds that estate agents are also jumping for joy at Carney’s announcement. Marsh and Parsons, which has more than a dozen offices across the wealthier parts of London, says Carney has “given the UK’s housing market a significant boost.” But for savers, the gloom continues. Funding for Lending has already depressed cash Isa rates, and today’s announcement means that savers will be hard-pressed to find returns anywhere much above 2% for some time to come. The early reaction to the Bank of England's new policy is decidedly mixed. TUC general secretary Frances O'Grady has welcomed the focus on unemployment, saying: Today's announcement shows that the bank understands a real recovery is something that benefits ordinary people, and not just an upward blip in economists' outlooks. The new governor's outlook also provides a much needed dose of realism after yesterday's 'Boom Britain' headlines But Mark Ostwald of Monument Securities reckons it's a 'big mistake' UK ILO [International Labour Organisation] labour data may be better "qualitatively" than many other official statistical series, but as the MPC has discussed in hushed tones (due to the political and social sensitivity) in previous minutes, it is difficult to assess how many of the longer-term unemployed are in fact largely unemployable... We're collecting all the analyst reaction to today's news, here: Bank of England inflation report: what the economists say Here's our news story about the Bank of England announcing that it will link interest rates to the UK's jobless targets: Bank of England links interest rates to jobless target The Bank of England has tied a rise in interest rates to a drop in the unemployment rate to 7%. The dramatic announcement means the economy will need to generate around another 750,000 jobs before the central bank considers hiking rates from their current all-time low of 0.5%. This, combined with rising wages, would represent "real improvements in the lives of people across the nation" said new Bank governor Mark Carney. Unveiling a new strategy of forward guidance, Carney said a further boost to quantitative easing was also possible while unemployment remained above the 7% threshold. Full story here. Are you impressed by Mark Carney's first big announcement, or are you alarmed by today's developments? Vote here: Has Mark Carney lived up to expectations? Our economics correspondent, Phillip Inman, suggests that Mark Carney might have favoured an even lower unemployment target: Louise Cooper of CooperCity isn't impressed that the Bank has identified a medium-term inflation rate of 2.5% as one of its 'knockout' factors that could force it to drop the unemployment target. Given the official inflation target is 2%, is the Bank going soft on the cost of living? (note. As explained at 11.13am Carney did deny that the inflation target had been raised when challenged about it). Stephen Evans, a former staffer at the Treasury, backs Mark Carney's view that the UK economy is still relatively weak: David Smith of the Sunday Times sums the press conference up: The press conference -- one of the most interesting we've seen at the Bank of England for some time -- is now over. Reaction, analysis, details ,etc etc, to follow... One more interesting reply from Mark Carney. Asked by Faisal Islam of Channel 4 whether today's announcement is "clarification" or "further loosening" , Carney is adamant that it's "clarification". This is about reassuring businesses and individuals about the future path of interest rates under current monetary policy -- making the current stimulus measures "more effective'. Hugh Pym of the BBC asks Carney why the Bank of England needs to announce new guidance today, when the economy is recovering. Carney minces no words, saying: This is the weakest economy on record, and those records go back more than one hundred years. There is significant slack.... and [the danger is that] the understandable feeling builds up that the Bank will start to pull back on the monetary stimulus packages [that have helped create the recovery]. The MPC is saying is that we need to make further progress....before we start to pull back, he adds. Ed Conway of Sky News asks for clarity about Mark Carney's suggestion that the Bank was not ruling out further asset purchases (quantitative easing) if needed. If that happens, are gilts (government debt), the right thing to buy? Carney declines to comment on that today, and points out that he'd only have one voice among nine if, and when, the Monetary Policy Committee considered the issue. Another question -- how serious is the situation in the eurozone crisis? Carney says that "there has been important progress, and there remains important work to do" to create a stable monetary union and get the eurozone economy back to growth. The pound fell sharply at 10.30am, but rallied during today's press conference as the markets digested Carney's words. (via Michael Hewson of CMC Markets). To be clear, there are three caveats, or "Knockouts", that the Bank has agreed in return for pledging to leave monetary policy unchanged until the unemployment rate falls to 7%. • if inflation in 18 to 24 months time threatens to be more than 0.5 above target, • if inflationary pressures are building over medium term, • and if there is risk to financial stability that can't be contained using other tools. From the press conference, our economics editor Larry Elliott reports that this is a "very big change" to monetary policy from the Bank of Engand. He reports: BoE has set a 7% unemployment threshold for raising interest rates. That means at the current rate of improvement interest rates will not rise this side of general election in 2015. QE will also not be reversed until the 7% threshold is reached. Larry added that the new governor gave "a deadpan opening statement". None of Sir Mervyn King's sporting metaphors. Perhaps Carney felt that ice hockey analogies would be wasted on the London press pack If you're just joining us, the Bank of England's historic press conference is being streamed here. And our coverage starts at 10.30am Phil Aldrick of the Daily Telegraph asks whether the Bank is risking a dangerous, "unbalanced" recovery. He also seeks details about how the Financial Policy Committee could 'knock out' the new unemployment target if it has concerns about financial stability. Carney replies: In a global economy that remains relatively weak, and with our largest trading partner moving sideways, the path to sustainable recovery is to increase productivity. So, the FPC could raise a red flag if it thinks conditions are taking the wrong turn. Deputy governor Charlie Bean elaborates -- The UK economy needs to be rebalanced, but this isn't the ideal environment for it. Firms need help and certainty if they're going to increase business investment, he adds. Question: Has the Bank of England effectively raised its inflation target, from 2% to 2.5%, by saying that it could abandon the aim of a 7% unemployment rate if inflation is heading above 2.5% on a 18 to 24-month horizon? Carney denies it. The MPC is still committed to a 2% rate. And with CPI at 2.9% last month, it has work to do. Claire Jones of the Financial Times asks whether the MPC was unanimous in choosing a 7% unemployment rate as the new measure of the UK's financial health. Carney refuses to reveal the answer. As with all MPC decisions, you'll have to wait for the minutes to find out, he smiles.... Hugo Duncan of the Daily Mail asks if the UK banking sector is strong enough to take advantage of the ultra-low monetary policy being promised today. Carney replies that "considerable progress" has beem made improving the resilisnce of the banking sector -- many building societies and "nearly all banks" meet the new risk measurement, called the 'leverage ratio' (Barclays is the laggard, and announced a rights issue to raise capital last week). Carney is positive about prospects, saying: The ability to provide lending to the real economy has improved. Jennifer Ryan of Bloomberg News asks the Governor why the Bank has raised its growth forecasts today -- it now expects GDP to rise by 0.6% in the third quarter of this year, rising to 2.6 per year in two years. Carney cites "a variety of hard and soft data", including from the Bank's agents around the country, back up the view that the economy is recovering. Ben Chu of the Independent asks if the UK has reached 'escape velocity' - one of Carney's big themes. No, Carney replies. Sam Fleming of the Times asks how much faith the public can have in the new forecasts, Carney says there are 'specific sensitivities' in the Bank's new thinking (see 10.42am) to underpin the accuracy of its assessment. Not everyone will agree, though, he admits: People will have different views. That's entirely reasonable. Today's plan, though, is an opportunity to "coalesce" views around the conditions under which monetary policy should be tightened. And if the recovery faltered, or a member of the Monetary Policy Committee felt that additional stimulus was needed, she or he could argue for it, Carney adds. What keeps you up at night, governor, asks Guy Falconbridge of Reuters, who helpfully suggests the UK Help To Buy scheme. Carney replies that his biggest fear is that: As the recovery gathers pace, there is an unwarranted expectation about the pace of the withdrawal monetary policy stimulus. Thus the need for forward guidance. Carney also gently refutes concerns over Help to Buy -- a new plan to help people buy homes. He says: • Mortgate applications below historical averages - below 60,000 per month, and the Bank would expect an increase • High loan-to-value morttages are only 40% of the market - not 70% at the height of the boom • Valuations are still 'quite a way off' historic highs. Bill Keegan of the Observer gets the second question - to what extent is fiscal policy helping to get unemployment down to the 7% threshold set today? Mark Carney says that the Bank seeks stable inflation at the 2% target -- but it is determined to give "due consideration" to output and unemployment do to that. Carney insists that unemployment is not a "target": It's the best summary indicator of the condiations in the economy at which the MPC would begin to withdraw the exceptional monetary stimulus that is in place. Over to questions... and our economics editor Larry Elliott gets the first one. What proof is there that UK unemployment and inflation are linked? In other words, what basis is the Bank working on when it says that the unemployment target could be abandoned if inflation is heading over the 2.5% rate in the medium term? The key question, Carney says, is now much slack there is in the UK economy today. The MPC believes there is a margin of slack, a margin of productivity, that can be recovered as the economy recovers, he says. Here's a link to inflation report: Here's a link to forward guidance: A fall in unemployment, from 7.8% to 7%, would mean another 750,000 new jobs for the nation, Carney adds. Carney also says that the Bank of England could still launch more quantitative easing if needed, and it does not expect to unwind QE until the unemployment rate hits the 7% threshhold. Effectlvely, the Bank of England is suggesting that interest rates will remain at 0.5% for a year longer than the markets had expected. Crucially, this pledge to keep rates at record lows until the unemployment rate falls to 7% isn't set in stone. It could be set aside if the Bank feels that, on a medium-term timescale, the CPI measure of inflation will be above 2.5%. Currently, it's goal is to keep inflation near 2%. The MPC will also use inflation expectations as a guide. Governor Mark Carney is explaining the new policy now. He says that Britain is recoving from an unprecedented financial crisis, and that the unemployment rate is the biggest sign that the UK still needs help. Reminder - you can watch the Bank of England press conference here. Here's the details of the Bank's new policy on interest rates, from Reuters: The Bank of England plans to keep interest rates at a record low until unemployment falls to 7% - something unlikely for another three years - in a major new departure for British monetary policy. Barely a month after Canadian Mark Carney took over from the long-serving Mervyn King as BoE governor, the central bank said on Wednesday that it would keep interest rates at 0.5 percent unless inflation threatened to get out of control or there was a danger to financial stability . "Until the margin of slack within the economy has narrowed significantly, it will be appropriate to maintain the current exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy," the BoE said. BoE policymakers said they stood ready to buy more government bonds if additional stimulus was needed and would not reverse existing purchases while unemployment was too high. The BoE said that growth was likely to be "weak by historical standards", even though economic recovery was "taking hold" and inflation was forecast to stay above its 2 percent target until the second half of 2015 based on market rate expectations. "Attempting to return inflation to the target too quickly risks prolonging the period over which the nation's resources are underutilised," the central bank said. BREAKING: The Bank of England has tied future interest rates to unemployment levels. They will stay low until the jobless rate hits 7%. It's 7.8% today. You can always rely on the Financial Times for accuracy... Any moment now..... The Bank of England is live-streaming today's quarterly inflation report press conference on its website, ahead of the 10.30am start. It's a good service, as it also includes key pages from the report itself. Click here to see it (perhaps a new browser tab....) There's currently a 'lock-in' for newswire reporters at the Bank, so the details of the report should emerge at 10.30am sharp, when Mark Carney will also start speaking.. Jonathan Pryor of Investec Corporate Treasury reminds us that the Bank of England will also announce new GDP forecasts this morning, and probably predict stronger growth: He writes: Away from the Bank of England’s announcements today, growth projections will be eagerly awaited. We saw a rise in Q2 GDP, which climbed 0.6% and this was followed by the Bank of England suggesting we could well see an increase in growth through Q3. As such, many are expecting to see a rise in the GDP forecast for both the remainder of 2013 and 2014. If this prediction is correct then the adage of ‘you can’t take with both hands’ will come into play as a firmer GDP number will no doubt suggest inflationary pressure. Three months ago, at the last quarterly inflation report, the Bank raised its GDP forecast for 2013 to more than 1% growth, from 0.9%. That does look conservative, as Britain has already posted 0.3% growth in Q1, and 0.6% in Q2. I mentioned in the opening post that governor Carney had made a 'sure-footed' start to his time at the Bank of England. Well, Louise Cooper, analyst at CooperCity, agrees, but points out that the hard work starts now. Taking the tube to work on your first day, unveiling Jane Austen as the (worthy) face of the next ten pound note, and persuading the doves at the Bank of England to stop squawking about more quantitative easing is the easy bit of Governing, she writes: Trained as an investment banker at Goldman Sachs, it should be no surprise that Carney is a smooth operator. From his first day when he arrived at Threadneedle Street by public transport rather than the chauffeured car, he has demonstrated his skills. He announced that Jane Austen is to be the female face on a Bank of England ten pound note. And he has turned a split MPC into agreement on QE. Today's announcement will be a further test to his power and abilities - quite how far he can go? Whatever is announced today, this is a man on a mission to create growth - highly useful for the Tories ahead of the 2015 election. Under Carney it is clear that GDP is more important than fighting inflation. His arrival is clearly good for the indebted and offers yet more pain for savers. Recent upbeat economic news makes setting forward guidance harder, she adds. Carney, of course, is getting a handsome salary and housing allowance to make the right calls. As Andrew Clark pointed out in The Times yesterday: We’re about to find out whether the man from Alberta is worth the hype, the political capital and the big house in West Hampstead. The Times: Dilemma to test Mark Carney’s worth (£) The pound has fallen against the US dollar this morning, shedding almost half a cent to $1.5301. It's broadly flat against the euro, though, at €1.152. The big mover overnight is the Japanese yen, up almost one percent to 96.9 yen against the dollar - a six-week high. That sparked a rout on Japan's stock market. The Nikkei tumbled 4% on fears that the country's huge stimulus package - which relies on a weak yen - was losing momentum. In the reader comments, Halo572 is struck by Carney's ability to grab the limelight: Poor Uncle Lord Sir Mervyn, off standing by the sea shouting at it to not come in and disobey him, another nail in his tenure's coffin as the greatest economic showman on Earth shows him how it really should have been done. And wishfulfilment is also critical: Economics lecturer Stephen Kinsella tweets that we might be getting a little carried away.... City analysts are also intruiged about the prospect of forward guidance from the Bank of England. Kit Juckes of Societe Generale cautions about not getting carried away: BOE Governor Mark Carney’s success with forward guidance in Canada is part of his CV, but ‘reaching over the heads of markets’ and telling the people of the UK that rates will stay low for a long time, won’t have so much effect. Rate expectations are already low. As for markets, the biggest effect may be on inflation expectations. Jane Foley of Rabobank reckons that Carney will not nail the Bank's trousers to an explicit target, such as the unemployment rate: Our expectation is that forward guidance used by the Bank will be simple and not tied to the performance of a particular economic variable. Speculation that the MPC could commit to maintain accommodative policy settings until a certain economic threshold has been reached appears to be based on the Federal Reserve’s current focus on the unemployment rate. However, the Fed has had a mandate to target employment for years, the BoE has not. webTitle: Bank of England links interest rates to jobless target

fields.standfirst: New governor Mark Carney talks of a 'renewed recovery' in UK economy, but warns of threat from high unemployment
fields.body:
The UK economy will need to generate around 750,000 more jobs before the Bank of England considers lifting interest rates from their current all-time low of 0.5%, the central bank's new governor, Mark Carney, has announced.

Unveiling a new strategy of forward guidance, Carney said a further boost to quantitative easing was also possible while unemployment remained above the 7% threshold.

On the current trend for unemployment, which stands at 7.8%, it is likely to take three years for the bank to reach its target, comforting businesses and homebuyers who can continue to borrow at low rates until at least 2016.

Carney said this, combined with rising wages, would represent "real improvements in the lives of people across the nation".

The governor said Britain had suffered an unprecedented financial crisis but that "a renewed recovery" was under way. The Bank raised its growth forecasts, predicting economic growth would reach an annual rate of at least 2% by the end of 2013 – a year sooner than previously predicted.

"There are clear signs that economic activity has strengthened this year," Carney said. "But there should be little satisfaction. Much is at stake as we seek to secure this recovery and return inflation to target."

The unemployment rate was the biggest sign that the UK still needs help, Carney said. "Until the margin of slack within the economy has narrowed significantly, it will be appropriate to maintain the current exceptionally stimulative stance of monetary policy."

Concerns that the current recovery, which has seen GDP rise 0.9% in the first six months of the year, could increase inflation beyond the bank's 2% target were dismissed by Carney, although he said inflation remained a primary concern.

Inflation was unlikely to rise above 3% this year – lower than previous fears of a peak of around 3.5%.

Carney said the unemployment target could be abandoned should the bank's internal analysis show GDP growth was the cause of a rise in prices of more than 2.5% in two years' time.

The Bank said: "While job growth has been a relative positive in recent years, unemployment is still high.

"There are one million more people unemployed today than before the financial crisis; and many who have jobs would like to work more than they currently can. The weakness in activity has also been accompanied by exceptionally weak productivity. It is for these reasons that the MPC [monetary policy committee] judges there to be a significant margin of slack in the economy, even though the extent of that slack, particularly the scope for a productivity rebound, is very uncertain".

The US Federal Reserve, which has continued to expand its stimulus package despite a strong recovery, has tied a rise in interest rates to an unemployment rate of 6.5%, which analysts expect will be reached by the summer of 2015. Like Carney, Fed boss Ben Bernanke has said reaching the target will only trigger a debate about raising rates, not an immediate hike.

There is a lively debate among economists over the amount of slack in the economy. The MPC, which Carney chairs, has appeared split in recent months over the need for further stimulus for the economy and the likely benefit of providing forward guidance.

The Bank's chief economist Spencer Dale, and Carney's right-hand man Charlie Bean, a deputy governor, had made speeches outlining the possible problems of locking the Bank's decision-making to specific economic data.

It seems that Carney has persuaded the committee to side with economists who say that unemployment is a sure sign that the economy remains weak and can generate extra supply without causing inflation.

Threadneedle Street has picked 7% as the "natural rate" of unemployment. A lower level of unemployment may begin to generate labour shortages in some areas and drive up wages and inflation.

Critics of the central bank argue that the recession following the banking crash destroyed a slice of the UK's productive capacity and that the extra demand created by low interest rates would be met by producers not with extra supply, but with higher prices.

There are also concerns that a commitment to keep interest rates low will trigger a house price boom, leading to an unsustainable bubble.

Vicky Redwood, chief UK economist at Capital Economics, said the Bank's move means rates were unlikely to rise until 2016 or even later.

"[The MPC] does not intend to raise interest rates until unemployment falls below 7%. Admittedly this is not too far below the current unemployment rate of 7.8%," she said. "But the MPC sees scope for a period of strong GDP growth driven by a rebound in productivity growth. So its forecasts published today show that it does not expect unemployment to drop below 7% until after the end of the forecast horizon (i.e. after Q3 2016). So this is a clear steer that interest rates will stay on hold until the end of 2016 or even 2017."

Chancellor George Osborne welcomed the introduction of forward guidance by the Bank. In a letter to Carney, Osborne said: "Given the exceptional economic challenges continuing to face the UK economy, I agree with you that forward guidance can play a useful role in enhancing the effectiveness of monetary policy and thereby supporting the recovery."

But, despite mounting signs that Britain's recovery is picking up pace, Carney dampened recent hopes that the UK had returned to an economic boom, saying: "We are not at escape velocity right now."

webTitle: Focus on wealthy travellers pays off for Tui Travel

fields.bodyText: The world's largest tour operator is flying high as a rise in bookings at its exclusive hotels and resorts helped lift profits. Tui Travel, the owner of Thomson and First Choice, reported an 18% increase in profits to £87m for the three months to the end of June – a headline figure that was dampened by an early Easter that meant, unlike 2012, Easter profits were booked in the previous quarterly results. The travel agent, which also owns six European airlines, continues to benefit from being a pioneer of the more upmarket package holiday, offering customers exclusive access to hotels, as well as "concept" resorts targeted at particular groups: Splashworld for families and water-slide enthusiasts, Thomson Couples for those who want a child-free holiday. Bookings for these holidays were up 14% in the UK, 11% in the Nordic countries and 9% in Germany, while the average price of a holiday was also higher in all regions. Peter Long, chief executive of Tui Travel, said he was "very confident of achieving full year underlying operating profit growth of at least 10% on a constant currency basis". The robust results come a week after rival Thomas Cook reported it had swung back into profit for the first time since staving off bankruptcy two years ago. Tui has sold 84% of its summer holidays, a slight improvement on last year, which puts it almost level with Thomas Cook, which has sold 85%. Tui has also sold around one fifth of its winter breaks for the 2013-14 season. The company now sells almost half (47%) of its holidays over the internet in the UK, while almost seven-in-10 (69%) packages sold to Nordic holidaymakers are done online. Shares in Tui Travel, which have risen by one fifth in recent months, were down 5% to 380p as investors took the chance to take profits.

webTitle: India calls on Raghuram Rajan to run its central bank

fields.standfirst: Former IMF economist will take over at the Reserve Bank of India as government tackles worst economic problems in two decades
fields.body:
India has turned to former International Monetary Fund economist Raghuram Rajan to run its central bank as the government of the world's second most populous country sought to tackle its most serious economic problems in more than two decades.

Rajan will take over at the Reserve Bank of India early next month amid fears that the much-debated phasing out of America's stimulus package will push up the value of the dollar and trigger a currency crisis in emerging markets.

With India the worst performing emerging market economy since the turn of the year, the arrival of one of the few economists to have forewarned about the risks posed by the speculative activities of global banks has been welcomed by analysts.

In a brief statement Rajan acknowledged the scale of the challenge he faces during his three-year term. He said that while "there was no magic wand to make the problems disappear instantaneously" the government and the central bank would work together to overcome the difficulties.

The new governor will arrive at a time when India faces a cocktail of economic problems – slowing growth, rising inflation, a wider current account deficit and an expanding budget shortfall – that has prompted comparisons with the crisis of 1991,which triggered widespread reforms in Asia's third biggest economy.

After being one of the emerging world's star performers during the financial crisis and its immediate aftermath, India has recently been suffering from a form of stagflation. Consumer prices are rising at an annual rate of almost 10%, while the latest forecasts from the central bank suggest that growth came to a standstill in the second quarter of 2013.

Monetary policy has been tightened in recent months in an attempt to stem the fall in the value of the rupee, which hit a record low of 61.80 against the US dollar on Tuesday before rallying slightly on news of Rajan's appointment.

Bhanu Baweja, head of emerging markets strategy at UBS in London, said: "He has the intellectual pedigree and policy experience but my worry is people will think a smart guy coming in will fix all of India's problems.

"The problem in India is political consensus and execution. By itself the appointment doesn't change my view on the market. I am underweight the rupee and Indian equities," Baweja said.

Shweta Singh at Lombard Street Research said India's twin deficit – the current account and budget deficit combined – stood at 12% of national output, just shy of the 14% of GDP recorded during the 1991 crisis. "With quantitative easing tapering (in the US) the talk of the town, investors are getting increasingly wary of financing the deficit and a potential re-run of the 1991 crisis."

India's new central bank governor was the chief economist at the IMF in the bubble years of 2003-2006, and warned that the flawed business model being used by the financial sector could lead to a collapse. Rajan's warnings were dismissed at the time, with Larry Summers – tipped to take over from Ben Bernanke as chairman of the US Federal Reserve – describing them as "misguided".

After leaving the IMF, Rajan returned to academia in the US before becoming senior adviser at India's finance ministry last year. In retrospect he has been hailed as one of the few senior policymakers to identify the dangers involved in banks allegedly laying off risks through the use of highly complex financial instruments.

Rajan, who replaces Duvvuri Subbarao, wants to create a monetary policy committee at the central bank, changing the current system under which decisions are taken by the governor alone.

webTitle: Gina Rinehart's attempt to subpoena reporter failed under shield laws

fields.standfirst: Judge rejected newspaper's other arguments but found laws introduced last year were all grounds needed to dismiss case
fields.body:
Gina Rinehart's attempt to force a journalist to reveal his sources was dismissed only on the basis of Western Australia's shield laws. All the other arguments from the newspaper's lawyers were rejected.

Rinehart subpoenaed the Walkley award-winning journalist Steve Pennells and the newspaper company he worked for to hand over all notes, recordings and communication in relation to her company Hancock Prospecting, her son, John Hancock, and the billion-dollar trust which is at the centre of a legal battle between Rinehart and two of her children.

Pennells and West Australian Newspapers (WAN) refused to do so, sparking a legal battle which ended on Tuesday in the first real test of WA's shield laws.

WAN tried to have the subpoena dismissed on several grounds including that it was oppressive, breached confidentiality, the scope was too large and it was an abuse of process but all arguments failed, the WA supreme court justice Janine Pritchard ruled.

She also dismissed an attempt by WAN to reject the subpoenas on the grounds of the "newspaper rule" which submits that it is in the public interest to maintain confidentiality agreements between journalists and their sources.

But Pritchard found that WA's shield laws – which were introduced last year – were the only grounds needed to reject the subpoena, and in relation to those laws the application was oppressive and an abuse of process.

"I have reached the conclusion that if Mr Pennells, or an officer of WAN, were called to give identifying evidence of the same kind as is contained in the documents sought, then on the basis of the information presently available, it is very unlikely that they could be compelled to do so," Pritchard said in her judgment.

"To require the production of documents containing the same identifying information under a subpoena would negate the very protection that the parliament has sought to create ...

"The result in this case does not mean that a subpoena for the production of documents held by a journalist or his or her employer could never be enforced."

The shield laws are split into two parts, the first relating to a variety of occupations and their right to protect information given to them confidentiality – such as accountants and sex counsellors.

The second part relates to journalists and whether they can be compelled to give evidence on the identity of their informants. The laws did not refer directly to subpoenas.

Rinehart's lawyers tried to prevent the judgment being made public but that application was dismissed by Pritchard.

The Fairfax journalist Adele Ferguson, who wrote an unauthorised biography of Rinehart, is still facing a court battle over a subpoena served on her by Rinehart demanding access to her source material for the book and other articles.

Ferguson's case remains at the directions stage and, after the judgment in the Pennells case, she said shield laws similar to those in WA should be in place across Australia.

"I think it is a great win for journalism and press freedom," she said. "The judgment was strong and made it clear that sources should be protected and journalistic ethics respected.

"But shield laws need to be stronger, as we can't leave it up to the courts to make a judgment on a case-by-case basis."

Pennells was in the court for the delivery on the judgment on Tuesday and called it "incredible".

"It's better than I ever dreamed of," he told Guardian Australia. "It effectively enshrines in law the sacred practices of journalism such as protection of sources and the public's right to know."

Rinehart's lawyers will argue next month for the case against WAN to be reopened.

fields.standfirst: Federal government says the six judges' unanimous rejection of mining company's challenge proves levy is constitutional
fields.body:
Fortescue Metals expressed its disappointment at the high court's unanimous decision to dismiss its challenge to the mining tax, describing the levy as "unfair, discriminatory and complex".

Fortescue's chief executive, Nev Power, said the company, whose case was supported by the Western Australian and Queensland governments, considered the minerals resource rent tax "an unreasonable intrusion into an area of state responsibility".

The federal government welcomed the court's decision, saying it demonstrated that the constitutional basis for the tax was sound.

But the future of the tax, which came into effect in July 2012, remains uncertain; the Coalition has pledged to abolish it.

"The good news is that if you vote for the Coalition the mining tax will be scrapped," the opposition leader, Tony Abbott, said after the decision.

Under the tax, companies pay 22.5% on profits above $75m from iron ore and coal production, though they can deduct state royalties first.

In a statement to the stock exchange, Fortescue Metals, which is owned by Andrew Forrest, thanked Abbott and the Coalition for standing by the mining industry with their promise to repeal the tax.

"Fortescue expects to pay $1.5bn in company tax and royalties this financial year, rising to $2bn in years ahead," Mr Power said.

The court ordered Fortescue to pay costs.

The company had argued that the mining tax was an unconstitutional interference by the commonwealth into states' functions and diminished their capacity to manage their resources.

It also said it breached a provision of the constitution that prohibits the commonwealth from discriminating between the states, owing to the different tax systems in different states.

A professor of law at the University of Melbourne, Michael Crommelin, said company and the states were concentrating their main argument on the view that the commonwealth could not use its powers in way that inhibited the states' essential functions.

"Queensland and Western Australia really concentrated on this point," Crommelin said. "They felt they had their best chance. They argued states had always managed their resources and these resources belonged to the states."

He said the six judges had found that that there was no formal discrimination by the commonwealth between the states in law.

The tax famously only raised $126m in its first six months, compared with a forecast $2bn, a result that former treasurer Wayne Swan put down to falling commodity prices.

In its pre-election economic statement, the federal government again revised down the revenue from the tax. Over the next four years it is predicted to bring in less than $4bn, instead of the forecast $5.3bn.
